properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snow expected late this evening into early Wednesday. Snowfall will likely become heavy at times for a few hours overnight with many areas receiving up to 15 cm by Wednesday morning. This snow is a result of a low pressure system from the Southern Plains States that will spread across parts of Northwestern Ontario tonight. The snow will quickly end Wednesday morning as the low races across Northeastern Ontario into Quebec. Hazardous winter driving conditions are expected tonight. Untreated roads may become snow covered and slippery. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-11T08:16:58-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-10T16:17:58-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2811569688.2020
Area: City of Thunder Bay, Beardmore - Jellicoe - Macdiarmid, Nakina - Aroland - Pagwa, Geraldton - Longlac - Caramat, Cloud Bay - Dorion, Kakabeka Falls - Whitefish Lake - Arrow Lake, Nipigon - Rossport
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain expected tonight into early Wednesday. A warm front through the area tonight will allow for freezing rain to develop for a few hours overnight. Precipitation may begin as rain late this evening and transition to freezing rain near midnight or early overnight as colder air from the north filters in and causes temperatures to drop to near or a little below the zero degree mark. Freezing rain will end Wednesday morning as the low races across Northeastern Ontario into Quebec. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-11T08:17:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-10T16:18:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1795791857.2020
Area: Manitouwadge - Hornepayne, White River - Dubreuilville, Fraserdale - Pledger Lake, Kapuskasing - Hearst - Smooth Rock Falls
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Civil Emergency, Update From Sk Provincial Emergency Communications Centre
properties.Summary:
Description: This emergency advisory alert is being issued for the province of Saskatchewan. All travelers returning from outside of Canada are subject to a mandatory 14 day self isolation order. Violation of the order may result in a fine of 2000 dollars.
Expires: 2020-11-25T12:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: SK Provincial Emergency Communications Centre, 2020-11-10T08:41:12-06:00, 84A0F065-000E-8323-6A3F-CD1303BFA9D6
Area: Province of Saskatchewan
properties.Author: SK Provincial Emergency Communications Centre

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wintry mix of precipitation expected later tonight into early Wednesday. Snow accumulations of 5 to 10 cm, along with ice pellets and a risk of freezing rain are possible tonight. Precipitation may begin as rain late this evening and transition to snow, ice pellets or freezing rain near midnight or early overnight as colder air from the north filters in and causes temperatures to drop below the zero degree mark. Precipitation will transition completely over to snow early in the morning and taper off later in the morning. Driving conditions may deteriorate tonight. Untreated roads may become icy and slippery. There is still some uncertainty to the axis of heavy snow and freezing rain. Snowfall warnings or freezing rain warnings may be required as this event draws closer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-11T08:35:19-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-10T16:36:19-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2805086921.2020
Area: Marathon - Schreiber
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain possible later tonight into early Wednesday. Rain or some wet snow ahead of a deepening low pressure area from the Southern Plains States will spread across Northern Ontario tonight. As colder air from the north filters in and causes temperatures to drop to near or a little below the zero degree mark, freezing rain may develop and persist for a few hours overnight. The freezing rain will end Wednesday morning as the low races across Northeastern Ontario into Quebec. Driving conditions may deteriorate tonight. Untreated roads may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings may be required as this event draws closer. . ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-11T02:49:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-10T10:50:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0658447408.2020
Area: Manitouwadge - Hornepayne, Marathon - Schreiber, White River - Dubreuilville, Wawa - Pukaskwa Park, Fraserdale - Pledger Lake, Kapuskasing - Hearst - Smooth Rock Falls, Little Abitibi - Kesagami Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Sasktel Service Outage In Kinoosao And Uranium City
properties.Summary:
Description: There is a service outage in Kinoosao and Uranium City affecting all SaskTel services in those communities. SaskTel crews are working to restore service as quickly as possible, however there currently is no estimated time of repair.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. An intense weather system is moving through the Arctic Islands. Strong easterly winds combined with falling snow will continue to produce blizzard conditions until late this morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 6 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-11-10T21:29:54-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-10T09:31:54-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3064510376.2020
Area: Resolute
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High concentration of pollutants are expected and will result in poor air quality, especially in urban areas where pollutant emissions are higher. High concentrations of pollutants are expected to persist until late this morning. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. In Quebec, wood heating is the main source of fine particles that contribute to smog during winter. This activity generates the largest number of these particulates, more than industrial activities and transportation. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada’s website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montréal, visit the Réseau de surveillance de la qualité de l’air de la Ville de Montréal’s website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Québec, visit the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux’s website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2020-11-10T20:59:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux, the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal, the City of Montréal, 2020-11-10T14:32:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0126171130.2020
Area: Portneuf area, Valcartier - Stoneham area, Québec area, Côte-de-Beaupré - L'Île d'Orléans area, Bellechasse area, Lévis area, Saint-Lambert area, Lotbinière area, Lac-Etchemin area, Sainte-Marie-de-Beauce area, Saint-Georges-de-Beauce area, Montmagny - Saint-Jean-Port-Joli area, Saint-Fabien - Saint-Pamphile area
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux, the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal, the City of Montréal

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: southwesterly 80 km/h, except 120 in the Canada Bay area. Time span: continuing until near midnight tonight. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-11-11T06:59:48-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-11-10T19:03:48-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4108526370.2020
Area: Northern Peninsula East
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. Location: Labrador City and Wabush area. Time span: overnight tonight until noon Wednesday. Remarks: Freezing rain will begin during the overnight hours tonight, and then transition to rain near noon Wednesday as temperatures rise above zero. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. Locations: Churchill Falls to Eagle River Time span: Wednesday afternoon into Wednesday evening. Remarks: Precipitation will begin as snow throughout the morning and then change to freezing rain near noon in Churchill Falls and Churchill Valley, and Wednesday afternoon in Goose Bay and Eagle River. Freezing rain will change to periods of rain in the evening as the temperature rises above zero. Motorists travelling the Trans-Labrador Highway will experience icy road conditions during this period. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect

Description: Heavy snow possible late this evening into early Wednesday. Snowfall may become heavy at times for a few hours overnight with many areas receiving up to 10 cm by Wednesday morning. This snow is a result of a low pressure system from the Southern Plains States that will spread across parts of Northwestern Ontario tonight. The snow will quickly end Wednesday morning as the low pressure area races across Northeastern Ontario into Quebec. Hazardous winter driving conditions are expected tonight. Untreated roads may become snow covered and slippery. Low visibility in heavy snow may also be an issue to deal with.
